meanings.definition: To establish or bring back into effect (a rule, practice, or system)
meanings.sent1: The school decided to reinstitute the old uniform policy.
meanings.sent2: The government plans to reinstitute the ban on single-use plastics.
meanings.sent3: The town council's attempt to reinstitute mandatory ice cream breaks during meetings was met with mixed reactions.
meanings.sent4: After the chaos, the teacher had to reinstitute order in the classroom.
meanings.sent5: The CEO's decision to reinstitute daily team meetings boosted productivity.

meanings.definition: To restore or revive (an organization or institution)
meanings.sent1: The new director aims to reinstitute the company's core values.
meanings.sent2: The community worked together to reinstitute the local library.
meanings.sent3: The mayor's plan to reinstitute the annual pie-eating contest brought joy to the town.
meanings.sent4: The coach's pep talk helped reinstitute the team's fighting spirit.
meanings.sent5: The charity's efforts to reinstitute hope in the homeless population were commendable.
